IMAGE-THUMBNAIL APCATA 14287 S0926-860X(13)00357-8 10.1016/j.apcata.2013.06.027 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD profiles of various Co/SiO2 catalysts (cobalt precursor: cobalt nitrate, impregnation method: incipient wetness): TD catalysts: (a) after drying, (b) after calcination at 773K, (f) after reduction at 773K. LT-SCD catalysts: (c) after calcination at 773K, (g) after reduction at 773K, HT-SCD catalysts: (d) after drying, (e) after calcination at 773K, (h) after reduction at 773K, (i) after reduction at 1073K. Fig. 2 TG reduction profiles for Co-M/SiO2 catalysts prepared by HT-SCD (cobalt precursor: cobalt nitrate, impregnation method: incipient wetness): (a) none, (b) rhenium, and (c) ruthenium. Fig. 3 TEM micrographs of TD and HT-SCD catalysts: (a) Co-Re/SiO2 (C-II, TD), (b) Co-Re/SiO2 (C-II, HT-SCD), (c) Histogram in the size of cobalt particles. Fig. 4 XRD profiles of calcined Co-Re/SiO2 prepared using various Co precursors (cobalt precursor, A: cobalt nitrate, B: cobalt acetate, C: hexa-ammine cobalt nitrate, D: hexa ammine cobalt acetate; impregnation method I: incipient wetness, II: evaporation-to dryness): (a) TD (A-II), (b) TD (B-II), (c) TD (C-II), (d) TD (D-II), (e) HT-SCD (A-II), (f) HT-SCD (B-II), (g) HT-SCD (C-II), (h) HT-SCD (D-II). Fig. 5 Relationship between CO conversion and olefin selectivities. Table 1 Effects of drying method on the cobalt crystallite size of the reduced Co/SiO2 catalysts.a Drying method Reduction temperature (K) Cobalt crystallite size (nm) TD 773 21.6 LT-SCD 773 18.0 HT-SCD 1073 10.4 aThe catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness. Cobalt nitrate was used as a cobalt precursor. Table 2 Catalytic properties of various Co-M/SiO2.a Additive Drying method Reduction temperature (K) Amount of H2 chemisorbed (cm3-STP/g) Cobalt particle size (nm) Cobalt dispersion (%) CO conversion (%) H2 chemisorption XRD H2 chemisorption XRD None TD 773 0.207 91.5 21.6 1.1 4.6 42 HT-SCD 1073 0.112 169.2 10.4 0.6 9.6 7 Re TD 773 0.232 81.7 19.3 1.2 5.2 60 HT-SCD 1073 0.340 55.7 5.7 1.8 17.5 65 Ru TD 773 0.336 56.4 15.5 1.8 6.4 71 HT-SCD 1073 0.171 110.8 5.3 0.9 18.8 65 aThe catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness. Cobalt nitrate was used as a cobalt precursor. Table 3 Comparison of Co 2p and Si 2p intensities in XPS of the catalysts before and after reduction. Catalyst Peak intensity (cps) Before reduction After reduction Co 2p Si 2p Co/Si Co 2p Si 2p Co/Si Co/SiO2(HT-SCD)a 1563 2833 0.55 625 11,111 0.06 Co-Re/SiO2(HT-SCD)b 3188 3222 0.99 3750 9944 0.38 Co-Re/SiO2(TD)b 2154 4893 0.44 2385 6500 0.37 aCobalt nitrate was used. bHexa-ammine cobalt nitrate was used. Table 4 Adsorption ratio of cobalt precursor on the support surface during impregnation.a Catalyst Adsorption ratio of cobalt precursor (%) Co-Re/SiO2(A) 1.0 Co-Re/SiO2(B) 0.6 Co-Re/SiO2(C) 16.1 Co-Re/SiO2(D) 14.0 aA: Cobalt nitrate, B: cobalt acetate, C: hexa ammine cobalt nitrate, D: hexa-ammine cobalt acetate. Fischer Tropsch synthesis over Co/SiO2 and Co-M (M: Ru, Re)/SiO2 catalysts prepared by a high-temperature super-critical drying method Hajime Iida ⁎ Kei Sakamoto Mariko Takeuchi Akira Igarashi Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Kogakuin University, 2665-1 Nakano-machi, Hachioji-shi, Tokyo 192-0015, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Kogakuin University 2665-1 Nakano-machi Hachioji-shi Tokyo 192-0015 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 42 628 4620; fax: +81 42 628 4993. Graphical abstract Co/SiO2-based catalysts for Fischer Tropsch synthesis (FTS) were prepared by a high-temperature super-critical drying (HT-SCD) method, and the effects of the drying method on the catalytic properties were investigated. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) of the calcined catalysts revealed that the cobalt species formed in the HT-SCD catalysts is mainly a less-reducible cobalt silicate (Co2SiO4-like species), whereas that formed in catalysts prepared by a conventional thermal drying (TD) is mainly the easily reducible Co3O4 species. Moreover temperature programmed reduction (TPR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and H2 chemisorption measurements revealed that the addition of rhenium or ruthenium to the HT-SCD catalysts improves the reducibility of the cobalt species and the cobalt dispersion, and partially suppresses the covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. The type of cobalt precursors used for catalyst preparation also had an effect on the cobalt species formed in the calcined catalysts. The HT-SCD catalysts with cobalt silicate exhibited higher olefin selectivities for FTS than the Co3O4-based catalysts prepared by TD, whereas the C11+ selectivities of the TD catalysts were higher than those of the HT-SCD catalysts. On the other hand, turn over frequency (TOF) estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed was constant without depending on the drying method and the type of cobalt precursors. Keywords Fischer Tropsch synthesis High-temperature super-critical drying Co-Re/SiO2 1 Introduction Fischer Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a major part of gas to liquid (GTL) technology, which converts syngas into clean fuels. Supported cobalt catalysts have been widely investigated for FTS due to their high activity, high selectivity toward long chain hydrocarbons, and low selectivity for the water–gas shift reaction [1,2]. The catalytic conversion of carbon monoxide occurs on active sites situated on the surface of cobalt metal particles dispersed on a porous support, so that the FTS rate is generally a function of cobalt dispersion and reducibility. Supports with a high surface area provide high cobalt dispersion and tend to produce highly active FTS catalysts, as long as the reducibility of cobalt oxide is not hindered by the interactions between the cobalt oxide and support [3]. Strong cobalt precursor–support interactions cause the formation of less-reducible mixed oxides such as Co2SiO4 and CoAl2O4 [4]. A high temperature is then required for the reduction of these oxides, which leads to extensive agglomeration and the formation of large cobalt metal particles. In contrast, weak cobalt precursor–support interactions cause the formation of readily reducible cobalt oxides. However, the weak cobalt precursor–support interactions lead to the agglomeration of small cobalt precursor crystallites during the drying and calcination steps. Therefore, the combinations of cobalt precursor and support with the moderate interaction strength are desirable for the preparation of highly dispersed cobalt catalysts [1]. The cobalt dispersion and reducibility of cobalt oxide are significantly influenced not only by the type of supports, but also by the preparation and activation procedures. Therefore, many investigations have focused on control of the characteristics of cobalt species using particular catalyst preparation methods. In previous reports, several factors during the preparation of supported cobalt catalysts, such as the pH of the impregnation solution and during the calcination conditions, have been suggested as having an effect on the characteristics of the cobalt species [5,6]. Mochizuki et al. reported that Co/SiO2 prepared from aqueous cobalt nitrate solution modified with certain chelating agents exhibited higher FTS activity than that prepared without the chelating agents, and the reason for the superior FTS activity was an increase in cobalt dispersion due to the formation of a highly dispersed α-Co2SiO4-like species during calcination [7]. Furthermore, promoters such as platinum, rhenium, and ruthenium have been used extensively to enhance the reducibility of cobalt oxide, which is otherwise limited by strong interaction between the oxide and supports such as alumina [2,6,8,9]. Among these promoters, rhenium is known as a structural promoter of supported cobalt catalysts. Rhenium acts to prevent agglomeration of CoO X particles during calcination treatment and leads to higher cobalt dispersion on the support without the change in the FTS turnover rates. Several reports have suggested that the reduction of Co3O4 to metallic cobalt may proceed via the formation of CoO as an intermediate. In addition, it has been proposed that rhenium enhances the reducibility of CoO to metallic cobalt, due to the effects of hydrogen spillover and autocatalytic reduction [10,11]. The conventional thermal drying method has some disadvantages such as the agglomeration of active metal salt due to the surface tension of solvent during the evaporation of solvent, which can lead to a low activity catalyst. Super-critical drying (SCD), which was first reported by Kistler [12], can prevent the condensation and effusion of active metals by capillary action due to the special characteristics of the supercritical fluid. Carbon dioxide has a low critical temperature (304K); therefore, it is useful as a fluid for SCD, because SCD can be conducted under mild conditions at a low temperature (LT-SCD) [13,14]. In contrast, SCD at a high temperature (HT-SCD) using organic solvents is applied for the preparation of supported metal catalysts [15]. The surface tension of solvents decreases at a higher temperature. A decrease in the surface tension suppresses the cohesion of metal precursor crystallites in the support pores during the drying step. Therefore, HT-SCD method is more effective for enhancing the metal dispersion compared to LT-SCD method. The present study is focused on control of the characteristics of the cobalt species due to the change in the drying method used for the preparation of supported cobalt catalysts. The effects of HT-SCD on the catalytic properties and performance of Co/SiO2 and Co-M (M: Ru, Re)/SiO2 catalysts were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Co/SiO2-based catalysts were prepared using an incipient wetness method or an evaporation-to-dryness method, as follows. The SiO2 support was obtained by calcining commercial silica (Q-50, Fuji Silysia Chemical) at 773K for 1h in a stream of air. For the incipient wetness method (denoted as I), an ethanol solution of cobalt nitrate was added to the support powder. For the preparation of Co-M (M: Ru, Re)/SiO2, an ethanol solution of the metal precursor was added to the support with the cobalt precursor. Ruthenium nitrate and ammonium perrhenate were used as ruthenium and rhenium precursors, respectively. The amount of ethanol was equivalent to the pore volume of SiO2 (1.0cm3 g−1). The cobalt concentration in the solution was adjusted to cobalt loading of 10wt%. For Co-M/SiO2, the M concentration in the solution was adjusted to a metal loading of 0.5wt%. After impregnation at 278K for 72h, the sample was dried by TD (373K, 0.1MPa, 15h), LT-SCD (313K, 10MPa, 1.0h), or HT-SCD (573K, 20MPa, 0.5h). The fluids used for LT-SCD and HT-SCD were carbon dioxide (Tc=304K, Pc=7.4MPa) and pentane (Tc=470K, Pc=3.3MPa), respectively. LT-SCD was conducted using a critical point dryer (HCP-2, Hitachi). HT-SCD was conducted using a fixed bed flow dryer under a high pressure. The procedure was as follows: pentane as the drying fluid was supplied to the dryer using a plunger pump. After the pressure was reached to 20MPa, the temperature was elevated to 573K for 1.5h and then was maintained at 573K for 0.5h. After that, the drying fluid was discharged from the dryer. The dryer then was cooled in an N2 stream. The dried sample was then calcined at 773K for 1h in a stream of air. For the evaporation-to-dryness method (hereafter II), an aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate (hereafter A), cobalt acetate (hereafter B), or hexa-ammine cobalt (III) cations, obtained by adding excess aqueous ammonia to cobalt nitrate (hereafter C) or cobalt acetate (hereafter D), was added to the support powder. The mixture was evaporated on a water bath at 373K. The resultant materials were then dried by HT-SCD or TD and finally calcined at 773K. 2.2 Activity test FTS was performed using a fixed bed flow reactor under a high pressure. The catalyst (1.0cm3) was mixed with quartz sand (1.0cm3) and placed in a quartz tube, which was then inserted into the stainless steel reactor. The HT-SCD catalysts were pre-reduced at 1073K for 1h in a stream of H2. The catalyst was subsequently reduced in the reactor at 773K for 1h in a stream of H2. After the catalyst was cooled to 503K in an N2 stream, the feed gas (30% CO, 60% H2, 10% Ar) was supplied to the reactor and the pressure was elevated to 2.0MPa. The space velocity (total) was 2000h−1. The reaction was continued from 3.5 to 6.0h. CO, CO2, and CH4 were quantified using an on-line gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), while C2–C10 hydrocarbons were quantified using an on-line gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID). The amount of C11+ hydrocarbons was calculated as follows: (1) C 11 + = [ moles of carbon in CO consumed ] − [ moles of carbon in hydrocarbons ( C 1 – C 10 ) and CO 2 formed ] The CO conversion and the selectivity for each product are defined as follows: (2) CO conversion ( % ) = moles of CO consumed moles of CO in the feed × 100 (3) Selectivity for each product ( % ) = moles of carbon in each product moles of carbon in all products × 100 2.3 Characterization The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption at 77K using a flow absorption apparatus (Flow Sorb II, Micromeritics). The measurements were conducted under mixed gas (N2:He=3:7) flow. Prior to measurement, the samples were degassed at 473K for 20min under the mixed gas flow. X-ray diffraction (XRD; RINT2000, Rigaku) analysis for the calcined and reduced catalysts was performed using Cu Kα radiation. The cobalt crystallite size of the reduced catalysts was calculated from the Co (111) peak using the Scherrer equation. The amount of chemisorbed H2 on the reduced catalysts was estimated using a volumetric absorption apparatus (ASAP2010, Micromeritics) with a chemisorption unit. Adsorption isotherms for H2 adsorbed on the catalysts were obtained at 308K. The cobalt dispersion was calculated from the size of cobalt crystallites or the amount of H2 chemisorbed as follows [16]: (4) D Co ( XRD ) = 6 ( v Co ) a Co d ( XRD ) where D Co is the cobalt dispersion, v Co is the volume of a cobalt atom, a Co is the sectional area of a cobalt atom, and d is the Co crystallite size measured by XRD analysis. (5) D Co ( H 2 ) = moles of H 2 chemisorbed on the catalyst × f moles of cobalt in the catalyst where f is the adsorption stoichiometry (Co/H2 =2.0). The cobalt particle size calculated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed on the catalyst as follows: (6) d ( H 2 ) = 6 ( v Co ) a Co D Co ( H 2 ) The turn over frequency (TOF) is defined as follows: (7) TOF = moles of CO consumed per second number of cobalt atoms exposed on the catalyst The number of cobalt atoms exposed on the catalyst was estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed and the cobalt crystallite size. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) measurements were conducted using a thermogravimetry-differential thermal analyzer (TG-DTA 2000, Mac Science) in an H2 stream. The ramping rate was 10Kmin−1. The adsorption ratio of various cobalt precursors on the SiO2 surface during the impregnation step was measured as follows. SiO2 powder (0.1g) was stirred into 20ml of a mixed solution of various cobalt precursor and ammonium perrhenate solutions (Co: 8.5mmoll−1, Re: 0.13mmoll−1) for 1.0h. After filtration, the resultant powder cakes were dried at 373K, and the cobalt concentration was then analyzed by X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) measurement. The XRF measurements were carried out using a SEA 1000A (Seiko Co. Ltd.). The adsorption ratio of cobalt precursor is defined as follows. (8) A Co = X ads. X Std. where A Co (−) is the adsorption ratio of the cobalt precursor, X ads. (cps) is the peak intensity of cobalt in the XRF spectrum for the Co-Re/SiO2 catalyst after drying, and X Std. (cps) is the peak intensity of cobalt in the XRF spectrum for the standard sample, which is Co/SiO2 with 10wt% Co loading. The microstructure of the Co-Re/SiO2 catalysts was observed after reduction, using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with a JEM-2010F microscope (JEOL), at an acceleration voltage of 200kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a quantum 2000 (Ulvac Phi) instrument with an X-ray Al anode. The beam diameter was 100μm, and an acceleration voltage was 15kV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of SCD on catalytic properties of Co/SiO2 Fig. 1 shows XRD profiles of various Co/SiO2 catalysts. These catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness method using cobalt nitrate as the precursor. Diffraction peaks assigned to Co3O4 were observed in the TD and LT-SCD catalysts after calcination (b, c), while peaks assigned to Co2SiO4-like species were evident for the HT-SCD catalyst (e), which confirms that the structure of the cobalt species present in the Co/SiO2 catalysts is affected by the drying method. The peaks of Co2SiO4-like species were already observed in the HT-SCD catalyst before the calcination, namely after the drying (d). Meanwhile, the peaks assigned to Co(NO3)2·nH2O and Co(OH)2 were observed in the TD catalyst before the calcination (a). The results indicate Co2SiO4-like species in the HT-SCD catalysts is formed during the drying step, while Co3O4 in the TD catalysts is formed during the calcination step. Coulter and Sault [17] have reported that the properties of cobalt species on Co/SiO2 catalysts, which are prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation with cobalt nitrate, exhibit a strong dependence upon the drying and calcining pretreatment conditions, namely the decomposition of cobalt nitrate during drying in air results in the formation of Co3O4 whereas the vacuum drying followed by vacuum annealing results in a highly dispersed cobalt silicate phase. Therefore, one of the reasons why Co2SiO4 like species is formed during HT-SCD step would be that the HT-SCD condition is non-oxidative. After reduction at 773K, diffraction peaks for metallic cobalt were observed for the TD and LT-SCD catalysts (f, g), while peaks assigned to Co2SiO4-like species were observed for the HT-SCD catalyst (h). Peaks of metallic cobalt were observed for the HT-SCD catalyst after reduction at 1073K (i), which indicates that the less-reducible Co2SiO4-like species mainly formed in the HT-SCD catalysts could be reduced at temperatures over 1073K. Table 1 shows the cobalt crystallite size of the reduced Co/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the TD and SCD methods. The cobalt crystallite size of the LT-SCD catalyst is smaller than that of the TD catalyst. In addition, the cobalt crystallite size of the HT-SCD catalyst reduced at 1073K was smaller than those of the TD and LT-SCD catalysts reduced at 773K. This infers that the strong interaction between cobalt oxide and SiO2 in the HT-SCD catalyst could prevent the sintering of cobalt particles. These results indicate that HT-SCD is an effective method for the preparation of highly dispersed Co/SiO2 catalysts. 3.2 Effects of secondary metal addition Noble metal promoters, such as platinum and ruthenium, are reduced at lower temperatures than the cobalt oxides, and catalyze cobalt reduction, presumably by hydrogen spillover from the promoter surface [10,11]. The addition of a small amount of noble metal shifts the reduction temperature of cobalt oxide and cobalt species interacting with the support to lower temperatures [1]. In the present study, the additive effects of ruthenium and rhenium on the HT-SCD catalyst were examined for an improvement of the reducibility of the cobalt species interacting with the SiO2 support. Fig. 2 shows TPR profiles for the Co-M/SiO2 (M: Ru, Re) catalysts. The peak assigned to the reduction of cobalt species was shifted to a lower temperature by the addition of rhenium or ruthenium to Co/SiO2, which indicates improved reducibility of the cobalt species in the HT-SCD catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the TEM micrographs of the rhenium added TD and HT-SCD catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3, spherical or hemispherical particles were observed in the micrographs. The particles on HT-SCD catalyst are remarkably smaller than those on the TD catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the mode diameters of particles on the HT-SCD and TD catalysts are 3 and 11nm, respectively. Moreover, the size distribution of particles on the HT-SCD catalyst is sharper than that on the TD catalyst. The catalytic properties and activities of various Co-M/SiO2 are summarized in Table 2 . The cobalt particle size and cobalt dispersion were estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed on the catalysts and Co (111) crystallite size. The cobalt particle size and cobalt dispersion estimated from XRD were similar to the dimensions of cobalt particles estimated from TEM micrographs. Although the HT-SCD catalyst without additive has smaller cobalt particles than the TD catalysts, the catalytic activity of the HT-SCD catalyst was much lower than that of the TD catalysts. The cobalt dispersion estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed on the HT-SCD catalyst without additive is extremely smaller than that calculated from XRD. Jabłoński et al. have reported that the H2 chemisorption capacity of Co/SiO2 catalysts was reduced by the reduction at the temperature over 973K and the cobalt particles over the catalysts reduced at 973K were covered with an amorphous adlayer probably SiO2 or SiO X migrating onto the particles [20]. In order to examine the covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer, XPS measurements were carried out for the reduced and calcined HT-SCD catalysts. In the XP spectra of the reduced HT-SCD and TD catalysts, the peaks (787 and 781eV) attributed to Co2+ were mainly observed [21]. This may mean the re-oxidation by the exposure to atmosphere between the pre-treatment and the XPS measurement. Therefore, it is difficult to discuss about the chemical state of cobalt using the obtained XP spectra. However, the covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer would be examined by the difference of the ratio of Co 2p to Si 2p between the calcined and reduced catalysts. Table 3 shows the Co 2p and Si 2p intensities in XPS of the catalysts before and after reduction. The ratio of Co 2p to Si 2p of the HT-SCD catalyst without additive was greatly decreased by the reduction at 1073K. This means the covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. Therefore, the poor activity of HT-SCD catalyst without additive would be caused by covering the cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. On the other hand, the addition of rhenium or ruthenium to the TD and HT-SCD catalysts caused an increase in the cobalt dispersion because the small amount of secondary metal acts as an anchor for cobalt particles and suppresses the sintering of cobalt particles during the reduction step [1,18,19]. As shown in Table 2, in the case of HT-SCD catalysts, the difference between the cobalt dispersion obtained from the H2 chemisorption and the value obtained from XRD, which would mean the degree of formation of SiO2 layer on cobalt particles, was decreased with the addition of rhenium and ruthenium. Especially, the addition of rhenium was effective for the suppression of covering of cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. Probably, the rhenium–cobalt interaction suppresses the migration of SiO2 on the cobalt particles. As shown in Table 3, the ratio of Co 2p to Si 2p of the rhenium added TD catalyst was little changed by the reduction at 773K. Although the ratio of Co 2p to Si 2p of the rhenium added HT-SCD catalyst was decreased by the reduction at 1073K, the loss was lower than that of the HT-SCD catalyst without additive. This result may indicate the suppression of migration of SiO2 on the cobalt particles. These are the reason why the catalytic activities of rhenium added HT-SCD catalysts exhibited higher CO conversion than that of the HT-SCD catalyst without additive. From the above facts, it indicates that the secondary metal, such as rhenium and ruthenium, is one of the necessaries for an increase in the catalytic activities of HT-SCD catalysts. 3.3 Effects of cobalt precursor and impregnation method The effect of the cobalt precursor on the catalytic properties of Co-Re/SiO2 was investigated. Fig. 4 shows XRD profiles of Co-Re/SiO2 prepared using various cobalt precursors. Co2SiO4-like species was present only in the HT-SCD catalysts prepared with ammine cations (C and D). Co2SiO4-like species was observed together with Co3O4 in both the HT-SCD catalysts prepared using cobalt nitrate (A) and cobalt acetate (B). In contrast, only Co3O4 was observed in the TD catalysts. Table 4 shows the adsorption ratio of cobalt precursor on the SiO2 surface during the impregnation step. The adsorption ratios of hexa-ammine cobalt cations (C and D) were higher than those of cobalt nitrate (A) and cobalt acetate (B). This means that the interaction between cobalt precursor and support on the Co/SiO2 (C and D) is stronger than that on the Co/SiO2 (A and B). Therefore, the strong interaction between cobalt precursor and support could accelerate a solid reaction between cobalt precursor and SiO2 during the drying step and results in the high concentration of cobalt silicate in the HT-SCD catalysts (C and D). Moreover during an elevating of drying temperature in the HT-SCD step, a rapid increase in temperature was observed on that particular case for the catalysts which are mainly formed Co2SiO4-like species, such as HT-SCD (C and D) catalysts. This result seems to be in agreement with the results of Girardon et al. [6], who reported that the exothermal decomposition of supported cobalt acetate complexes during the catalyst pretreatment leads to the migration of Co2+ ions to the silica core and results in the formation of cobalt silicate. On the other hand, van Steen et al. [22] have reported that increasing drying time caused a decrease in the amount of cobalt silicate and an increase in the amount of Co3O4. It was suggested in that work [22] that the precursor of the surface cobalt silicates is destroyed by the drying under a mild condition. A concentration of cobalt silicate in the HT-SCD (A-I) catalyst was higher than that in HT-SCD (A-II) catalysts. The former (A-I) was not heated before HT-SCD whereas the later (A-II) was heated during the evaporation-to-dryness. Therefore, a low concentration of cobalt silicate on HT-SCD (A-II) catalyst could be caused by the partial decomposition of the precursor during the evaporation-to-dryness. Table 5 shows the effects of the cobalt precursor and drying method on the catalytic properties of various Co-Re/SiO2. The cobalt particle size estimated from XRD on the HT-SCD catalysts was generally smaller than that on the TD catalysts, whereas the cobalt particle size estimated from H2 chemisorption on the HT-SCD was excessively larger than that on the TD catalysts. This means the surface of cobalt particles on the HT-SCD catalysts is partially covered with SiO2 layer, and results in a decrease in the amount of H2 chemisorption. In addition, the cobalt particle size of HT-SCD (A-I) was similar with that of HT-SCD (A-II). This means that the cobalt dispersion is little affected by the agglomeration of cobalt salt during evaporation of the solvent, contrary to the HT-SCD effect expected at first. TOF estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed on the catalysts was little changed by the drying method and the type of cobalt precursor, although TOF estimated from XRD of TD catalysts was larger than that of the HT-SCD catalysts. The values estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed on the catalysts were more appropriate because the amount of H2 chemisorbed more exactly reflects the amount of active site. TOF of cobalt species in FTS was discussed by many researchers. Among them, Iglesia reported that cobalt dispersion does not affect the rate of FTS [23]. Bezemer et al. have shown that TOF was constant for cobalt particles ranging from 6 to 27nm whereas TOF was much lower for cobalt particles smaller than 6nm [24]. Our results agree with their findings. Fig. 5 shows the relationship between the CO conversion and olefin selectivities. The olefin selectivities for the catalysts with Co2SiO4-like species were higher than those for the catalysts with Co3O4 at the same CO conversion. Table 6 shows the catalytic activities and selectivities of various Co-Re/SiO2. The C2–C3, C2 –C3 , C4–C10, and C4 –C10 fractions for the HT-SCD catalysts were larger than those for the TD catalysts, whereas the C11+ fraction for the TD catalysts was higher than that for the HT-SCD catalysts. These results indicate that the secondary reaction from light olefins to heavy hydrocarbons occurs more easily over the TD catalysts than over the HT-SCD catalysts. The difference between TD and HT-SCD catalysts could be explained by the degree of covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. 4 Conclusions The effects of catalyst preparation factors such as the drying method, the addition of secondary metals (Ru, Re), and the type of cobalt precursors used, on the catalytic properties of Co/SiO2 were investigated. Less-reducible cobalt silicate was generally formed on the HT-SCD catalysts, whereas Co3O4 was formed on the TD catalysts. The addition of rhenium to Co/SiO2 prepared by the HT-SCD method improved the reducibility of the cobalt species and the cobalt dispersion, and suppressed the covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. The type of cobalt precursors and drying method had an effect on the cobalt species formed on the catalysts after calcination. The HT-SCD catalysts with Co2SiO4 had higher olefin selectivities than the TD catalysts with Co3O4. However, the C11+ selectivities of the TD catalysts were higher than those of the HT-SCD catalysts. Catal. 137 1992 212 224 [24] G.L. Bezemer J.H. Butter H.P.C.E. Kuipers H. Oosterbeek J.E. Holewijn X. Xu F. Kapteijn A.J. Dillen K.P. de Jong J. Am. Chem. Soc. 128 2006 3956 3964

coredata.dc:description: Co/SiO2-based catalysts for Fischer Tropsch synthesis (FTS) were prepared by a high-temperature super-critical drying (HT-SCD) method, and the effects of the drying method on the catalytic properties were investigated. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) of the calcined catalysts revealed that the cobalt species formed in the HT-SCD catalysts is mainly a less-reducible cobalt silicate (Co2SiO4-like species), whereas that formed in catalysts prepared by a conventional thermal drying (TD) is mainly the easily reducible Co3O4 species. Moreover temperature programmed reduction (TPR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and H2 chemisorption measurements revealed that the addition of rhenium or ruthenium to the HT-SCD catalysts improves the reducibility of the cobalt species and the cobalt dispersion, and partially suppresses the covering cobalt particles with SiO2 layer. The type of cobalt precursors used for catalyst preparation also had an effect on the cobalt species formed in the calcined catalysts. The HT-SCD catalysts with cobalt silicate exhibited higher olefin selectivities for FTS than the Co3O4-based catalysts prepared by TD, whereas the C11+ selectivities of the TD catalysts were higher than those of the HT-SCD catalysts. On the other hand, turn over frequency (TOF) estimated from the amount of H2 chemisorbed was constant without depending on the drying method and the type of cobalt precursors.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer Tropsch synthesis over Co/SiO2 and Co-M (M: Ru, Re)/SiO2 catalysts prepared by a high-temperature super-critical drying method
